feed.title: Channing Tatum on Channing Tatum
feed.subtitle: From The Vow to Magic Mike, 2012 is the year of Channing Tatum, and "Chan" himself is giving Dose.ca the scoop on each of his coming attractions.

content.div:
LOS ANGELES - Some moviegoers may think of 2012 as the year of the Chan. They would be fans of Channing "Chan" Tatum, who has a string of five films hitting theatres.

They include a spy caper (Haywire), a romantic drama (The Vow), a comedy remake of a TV show (21 Jump Street), an action sequel based on a toy (G.I. Joe: Retaliation) and a biopic recalling Tatum's former night job as a male stripper (Magic Mike).

"I'm very proud of all the films," says the 31-year-old at a Beverly Hills hotel. "They're very different. If they were all the same, I would be freaking out, but they're not."

Let's get his take on the roster:

Haywire (opened Jan. 20)

Tatum plays a spy who faces off with a rogue agent (mixed-martial-arts champion Gina Carano) in this Steven Soderbergh fight-filled film, also featuring Ewan McGregor, Antonio Banderas, Bill Paxton and Michael Douglas.

In the opening sequence, Tatum squares off with Carano, who proves she can hold her own -- and then some.

"You know, I said to my wife once, 'Find me a girl who can whip my butt, and I will go to that movie,'" he recalls. "They finally did find one, so I said to Steven (Soderbergh), 'I want to be in the movie.' And he let me."

The actor enjoyed the experience for many reasons, but especially because of the realistic confrontations choreographed for the movie.

"Finally, there is a real action star who can do all those things," says Tatum of Carano in her major movie debut. "We did the fight scenes really quickly. And I wanted bruises, and I wanted stories to tell my buddies."

Unfortunately, Carano was so precise, she didn't leave a mark on him. "She's for real," Tatum says. "She only fakes it because she has to."

The Vow (opens Feb. 10)

Directed by Michael Sucsy, the movie stars Tatum, who plays a hip Chicago recording-studio owner. He tries to win back his wife, Paige, (Rachel McAdams) after she suffers severe memory loss resulting from a car accident.

It's a romance that counts on a strong bond between Tatum and McAdams, who starred in 2004's tear-jerker, The Notebook. And while Tatum says he tried his hand at a romance in 2010's Dear John, he mostly made his name as an action stud.

For The Vow, Tatum admits he got in touch with his inner, sensitive guy.

Says McAdams: "I'd always heard lovely things about Channing, but it's one thing to hear that, and another thing to experience it. He went above and beyond all expectations. He's the most open-hearted, generous, spirited person I know, and he doesn't do anything halfway."

21 Jump Street (opens March 16)

The film remake, based on the 1980s TV series that launched Johnny Depp's career, counts more on laughs than drama. It has Tatum and Jonah Hill playing undercover cops, posing as high-school students in order to bust a drug ring.

Tatum says he knew the action part of the movie would be a cinch. He was more concerned about the comedy element, so he relied on Hill, who earned an Oscar nomination for his comedic turn in Moneyball.

"I always put my faith in people that I admire, and that I love, and that I want to learn from," said Tatum. "Jump Street's one of the most fun things I've ever done."

He did have his doubts, initially. "The first week, I was like, 'I don't know if I can do this, because this is so strange,'" Tatum says of improvising lines.

Then Hill showed him how. "Jonah would stop in the middle of a take, and do a line a bunch of different ways, and each one was funnier than the last one."

Slowly, Tatum caught on. "It was so weird to do, but it works for comedy."

G.I. Joe: Retaliation (opens June 29)

The actor returns as Duke. "How could I resist?" says Tatum, who co-stars with Dwayne Johnson and Bruce Willis.

In the sequel, he's one of the G.I. Joe operatives caught up in a trap when the evil Cobra leader Zartan frames the special unit. The "Joes" are mistakenly identified as traitors, then nearly wiped out in an attack. Only a few survive, so they assemble to stop Cobra from taking over the world.

It's a popcorn flick with extra cheese, but that's what Tatum likes about it. "There's room for all kinds of entertainment," he says.

Magic Mike (opens this summer)

Tatum insists he was minding his own business on Steven Soderbergh's Haywire set when the director overheard the actor talking about working briefly as a stripper in Florida.

Soderbergh told Tatum he should get a writer to help him prepare a screenplay about his recollections. "So I did," says the actor. When Tatum showed the director his finished product, Soderbergh decided to co-produce and direct it after a few rewrites. "I couldn't believe it," recalls Tatum.

Also starring are Alex Pettyfer, Matt Bomer and Matthew McConaughey. "The movie has a hard R-rating," Tatum says. "It has lots of laughs, and lots of naked bodies, but not full-frontal."

So why did Tatum become a male stripper when he was 18?

"I was young and foolish," he says. "Those were my wild times."
